Award.AwardTitle: Social Pricing - Image Management, Social Preferences and Pay-What-You-Want

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project the Principal Investigators will study a relatively new pricing mechanism that challenges traditional economic theories. Under Pay-What-You-Want (PWYW) the customer determines how much to pay for the good (often including $0). In prior research the PI has found that a considerable portion of customers choose to pay something for goods and has proposed that this behavior is driven, at least in part, by image management concerns. The current project focuses on the role self and social image considerations have in PWYW purchases. A series of experiments will be conducted in which features of the seller-buyer relationship and type of interaction are systematically manipulated to identify the parameters that predict the success (and failure) of PWYW strategies and clarify the respective roles of self and social image concerns in PWYW decisions.

In terms of broader impact, this research will shed light regarding the role of non-standard motivations in the marketplace. In the process it will identify the conditions under which industries can sustain long-term profits using PWYW pricing, suggest how firms might want to go about modifying their pricing models, and suggest still other non-PWYW pricing strategies that might be optimal in light of the drives that make PWYW a profitable price mechanism.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Letting customers decide how much to pay for a product, including the option of paying nothing, seems like a sure way to go out of business. But, there is evidence suggesting that’s not always the case. A 2010 paper published in Science, showed that attendees at an amusement park were significantly more likely to buy a photo of themselves on a ride when offered using pay-what-you-want (PWYW), compared to when the photo was sold for the regular fixed price ($12.95). The average price paid per photo under PYWY was $0.92. When told that half the proceeds would go to charity, the number of buyers was cut by half, though the average price paid was significantly higher ($5.33). Building on these findings, this NSF funded project aimed to better understand why people pay when they can get a product of free, and what influences amount they pay.

 

Our research on pay-what-you-want pricing has yielded a few interesting insights. First, we have found that an individuals’ behavior is largely influenced by self-signaling motivations— a desire to feel that she is a good, fair, kind individual. Second, as the consequences associated of one’s payment increase, such as when a portion of that payment benefits a charity, consumers are often less likely to pay a small amount. The conflict between the desire to pay very little but at the same time to maintain a positive identity result with: a) lower purchase rates and b) higher average payments. Interestingly, individuals are only sensitive to whether any portion of their payment is allocated to a charity, and are entirely indifferent to the magnitude of that portion (whether it is 5%, 50%, or even 90%). This result suggests that payments in these cases in primarily driven by one’s motivation to feel good about herself, and not by her desire to benefit/help the cause.
